org.gradoop.flink.model.api.epgm

Interface LogicalGraphOperators

  • All Superinterfaces:
    GraphBaseOperators
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    LogicalGraph

    public interface LogicalGraphOperators
extends GraphBaseOperators
    Defines the operators that are available on a LogicalGraph.

    • Method Summary

      Applies the given aggregate functions to the logical graph and stores the result of those functions at the resulting graph using the given property keys.

      Generates all combinations of the supplied edge grouping keys according to the definition of the rollUp operation in SQL and uses them together with all vertex grouping keys for separate grouping operations.

    • Method Detail

      • cypher

        @Deprecated
GraphCollection cypher(String query)
        Deprecated. because of API restructuring. Please use LogicalGraph.query(String) instead.
        Evaluates the given query using the Cypher query engine. The engine uses default morphism strategies, which is vertex homomorphism and edge isomorphism. The vertex and edge data of the data graph elements is attached to the resulting vertices. Note, that this method used no statistics about the data graph which may result in bad runtime performance. Use cypher(String, GraphStatistics) to provide statistics for the query planner.
        Parameters:
        query - Cypher query
        Returns:
        graph collection containing matching subgraphs

      • cypher

        @Deprecated
GraphCollection cypher(String query,
                                   String constructionPattern)
        Deprecated. because of API restructuring. Please use LogicalGraph.query(String, String) instead.
        Evaluates the given query using the Cypher query engine. The engine uses default morphism strategies, which is vertex homomorphism and edge isomorphism. The vertex and edge data of the data graph elements is attached to the resulting vertices. Note, that this method used no statistics about the data graph which may result in bad runtime performance. Use cypher(String, GraphStatistics) to provide statistics for the query planner. In addition, the operator can be supplied with a construction pattern allowing the creation of new graph elements based on variable bindings of the match pattern. Consider the following example: 
         graph.cypher(
  "MATCH (a:Author)-[:WROTE]->(:Paper)<-[:WROTE]-(b:Author) WHERE a <> b",
  "(a)-[:CO_AUTHOR]->(b)")
        The query pattern is looking for pairs of authors that worked on the same paper. The construction pattern defines a new edge of type CO_AUTHOR between the two entities.
        Parameters:
        query - Cypher query string
        constructionPattern - Construction pattern
        Returns:
        graph collection containing the output of the construct pattern

      • cypher

        @Deprecated
GraphCollection cypher(String query,
                                   GraphStatistics graphStatistics)
        Deprecated. because of API restructuring. Please use LogicalGraph.query(String, GraphStatistics) instead.
        Evaluates the given query using the Cypher query engine. The engine uses default morphism strategies, which is vertex homomorphism and edge isomorphism. The vertex and edge data of the data graph elements is attached to the resulting vertices.
        Parameters:
        query - Cypher query
        graphStatistics - statistics about the data graph
        Returns:
        graph collection containing matching subgraphs

      • cypher

        @Deprecated
GraphCollection cypher(String query,
                                   String constructionPattern,
                                   GraphStatistics graphStatistics)
        Deprecated. because of API restructuring. Please use LogicalGraph.query(String, String, GraphStatistics) instead.
        Evaluates the given query using the Cypher query engine. The engine uses default morphism strategies, which is vertex homomorphism and edge isomorphism. The vertex and edge data of the data graph elements is attached to the resulting vertices. In addition, the operator can be supplied with a construction pattern allowing the creation of new graph elements based on variable bindings of the match pattern. Consider the following example: 
         graph.cypher(
  "MATCH (a:Author)-[:WROTE]->(:Paper)<-[:WROTE]-(b:Author) WHERE a <> b",
  "(a)-[:CO_AUTHOR]->(b)")
        The query pattern is looking for pairs of authors that worked on the same paper. The construction pattern defines a new edge of type CO_AUTHOR between the two entities.
        Parameters:
        query - Cypher query
        constructionPattern - Construction pattern
        graphStatistics - statistics about the data graph
        Returns:
        graph collection containing the output of the construct pattern

      • cypher

        @Deprecated
GraphCollection cypher(String query,
                                   boolean attachData,
                                   MatchStrategy vertexStrategy,
                                   MatchStrategy edgeStrategy,
                                   GraphStatistics graphStatistics)
        Deprecated. because of API restructuring. Please use LogicalGraph.query(String, boolean, MatchStrategy, MatchStrategy, GraphStatistics) instead.
        Evaluates the given query using the Cypher query engine.
        Parameters:
        query - Cypher query
        attachData - attach original vertex and edge data to the result
        vertexStrategy - morphism setting for vertex mapping
        edgeStrategy - morphism setting for edge mapping
        graphStatistics - statistics about the data graph
        Returns:
        graph collection containing matching subgraphs

                                   GraphStatistics graphStatistics)

        constructionPattern - Construction pattern
        attachData - attach original vertex and edge data to the result

        edgeStrategy - morphism setting for edge mapping

        graph collection containing matching subgraphs

      • query

        GraphCollection query(String query)
        Evaluates the given query using the Cypher query engine. The engine uses default morphism strategies, which is vertex homomorphism and edge isomorphism. The vertex and edge data of the data graph elements is attached to the resulting vertices. Note, that this method used no statistics about the data graph which may result in bad runtime performance. Use query(String, GraphStatistics) to provide statistics for the query planner.
        Parameters:
        query - Cypher query
        Returns:
        graph collection containing matching subgraphs

      • query

        GraphCollection query(String query,
                      String constructionPattern)
        Evaluates the given query using the Cypher query engine. The engine uses default morphism strategies, which is vertex homomorphism and edge isomorphism. The vertex and edge data of the data graph elements is attached to the resulting vertices. Note, that this method used no statistics about the data graph which may result in bad runtime performance. Use query(String, GraphStatistics) to provide statistics for the query planner. In addition, the operator can be supplied with a construction pattern allowing the creation of new graph elements based on variable bindings of the match pattern. Consider the following example: 
         graph.query(
  "MATCH (a:Author)-[:WROTE]->(:Paper)<-[:WROTE]-(b:Author) WHERE a <> b",
  "(a)-[:CO_AUTHOR]->(b)")
        The query pattern is looking for pairs of authors that worked on the same paper. The construction pattern defines a new edge of type CO_AUTHOR between the two entities.
        Parameters:
        query - Cypher query string
        constructionPattern - Construction pattern
        Returns:
        graph collection containing the output of the construct pattern

      • query

        GraphCollection query(String query,
                      String constructionPattern,
                      GraphStatistics graphStatistics)
        Evaluates the given query using the Cypher query engine. The engine uses default morphism strategies, which is vertex homomorphism and edge isomorphism. The vertex and edge data of the data graph elements is attached to the resulting vertices. In addition, the operator can be supplied with a construction pattern allowing the creation of new graph elements based on variable bindings of the match pattern. Consider the following example: 
         graph.query(
  "MATCH (a:Author)-[:WROTE]->(:Paper)<-[:WROTE]-(b:Author) WHERE a <> b",
  "(a)-[:CO_AUTHOR]->(b)")
        The query pattern is looking for pairs of authors that worked on the same paper. The construction pattern defines a new edge of type CO_AUTHOR between the two entities.
        Parameters:
        query - Cypher query
        constructionPattern - Construction pattern
        graphStatistics - statistics about the data graph
        Returns:
        graph collection containing the output of the construct pattern

        Returns:
        projected logical graph

      • transform

        LogicalGraph transform(TransformationFunction<GraphHead> graphHeadTransformationFunction,
                       TransformationFunction<Vertex> vertexTransformationFunction,
                       TransformationFunction<Edge> edgeTransformationFunction)
        Transforms the elements of the logical graph using the given transformation functions. The identity of the elements is preserved.
        Parameters:
        graphHeadTransformationFunction - graph head transformation function
        vertexTransformationFunction - vertex transformation function
        edgeTransformationFunction - edge transformation function
        Returns:
        transformed logical graph

        Returns:
        transformed logical graph

        Returns:
        transformed logical graph

        Returns:
        transformed logical graph

        Parameters:

      • subgraph

        default LogicalGraph subgraph(org.apache.flink.api.common.functions.FilterFunction<Vertex> vertexFilterFunction,
                              org.apache.flink.api.common.functions.FilterFunction<Edge> edgeFilterFunction)
        Returns a subgraph of the logical graph which contains only those vertices and edges that fulfil the given vertex and edge filter function respectively. Note, that the operator does not verify the consistency of the resulting graph. Use {#toGellyGraph().subgraph()} for that behaviour.
        Parameters:
        vertexFilterFunction - vertex filter function
        edgeFilterFunction - edge filter function
        Returns:
        logical graph which fulfils the given predicates and is a subgraph of that graph

      • subgraph

        LogicalGraph subgraph(org.apache.flink.api.common.functions.FilterFunction<Vertex> vertexFilterFunction,
                      org.apache.flink.api.common.functions.FilterFunction<Edge> edgeFilterFunction,
                      Subgraph.Strategy strategy)
        Returns a subgraph of the logical graph which contains only those vertices and edges that fulfil the given vertex and edge filter function respectively. Note, that the operator does not verify the consistency of the resulting graph. Use {#toGellyGraph().subgraph()} for that behaviour.
        Parameters:
        vertexFilterFunction - vertex filter function
        edgeFilterFunction - edge filter function
        strategy - execution strategy for the operator
        Returns:
        logical graph which fulfils the given predicates and is a subgraph of that graph

      • aggregate

        LogicalGraph aggregate(AggregateFunction... aggregateFunctions)
        Applies the given aggregate functions to the logical graph and stores the result of those functions at the resulting graph using the given property keys.
        Parameters:
        aggregateFunctions - computes aggregates on the logical graph
        Returns:
        logical graph with additional properties storing the aggregates

      • sample

        LogicalGraph sample(SamplingAlgorithm algorithm)
        Creates a new graph from a randomly chosen subset of nodes and their associated edges.
        Parameters:
        algorithm - used sampling algorithm
        Returns:
        logical graph with random nodes and their associated edges

      • groupBy

        LogicalGraph groupBy(List<String> vertexGroupingKeys)
        Creates a condensed version of the logical graph by grouping vertices based on the specified property keys. Vertices are grouped by the given property keys. Edges are implicitly grouped along with their incident vertices. Note: To group vertices by their type label, one needs to add the specific symbol Grouping.LABEL_SYMBOL to the respective grouping keys.
        Parameters:
        vertexGroupingKeys - property keys to group vertices
        Returns:
        summary graph
        See Also:
        Grouping

      • groupBy

        LogicalGraph groupBy(List<String> vertexGroupingKeys,
                     List<String> edgeGroupingKeys)
        Creates a condensed version of the logical graph by grouping vertices and edges based on given property keys. Vertices are grouped by the given property keys. Edges are implicitly grouped along with their incident vertices and explicitly by the specified edge grouping keys. One needs to at least specify a list of vertex grouping keys. Any other argument may be null. Note: To group vertices/edges by their type label, one needs to add the specific symbol Grouping.LABEL_SYMBOL to the respective grouping keys.
        Parameters:
        vertexGroupingKeys - property keys to group vertices
        edgeGroupingKeys - property keys to group edges
        Returns:
        summary graph
        See Also:
        Grouping

      • groupBy

        LogicalGraph groupBy(List<String> vertexGroupingKeys,
                     List<AggregateFunction> vertexAggregateFunctions,
                     List<String> edgeGroupingKeys,
                     List<AggregateFunction> edgeAggregateFunctions,
                     GroupingStrategy groupingStrategy)
        Creates a condensed version of the logical graph by grouping vertices and edges based on given property keys. Vertices are grouped by the given property keys. Edges are implicitly grouped along with their incident vertices and explicitly by the specified edge grouping keys. Furthermore, one can specify sets of vertex and edge aggregate functions which are applied on vertices/edges represented by the same super vertex/edge. One needs to at least specify a list of vertex grouping keys. Any other argument may be null. Note: To group vertices/edges by their type label, one needs to add the specific symbol Grouping.LABEL_SYMBOL to the respective grouping keys.
        Parameters:
        vertexGroupingKeys - property keys to group vertices
        vertexAggregateFunctions - aggregate functions to apply on super vertices
        edgeGroupingKeys - property keys to group edges
        edgeAggregateFunctions - aggregate functions to apply on super edges
        groupingStrategy - execution strategy for vertex grouping
        Returns:
        summary graph
        See Also:
        Grouping

      • reduceOnEdges

        LogicalGraph reduceOnEdges(EdgeAggregateFunction function,
                           Neighborhood.EdgeDirection edgeDirection)
        Sets the aggregation result of the given function as property for each vertex. All edges where the vertex is relevant get joined first and then grouped. The relevant edges are specified using the direction which may direct to the vertex, or from the vertex or both.
        Parameters:
        function - aggregate function
        edgeDirection - incoming, outgoing edges or both
        Returns:
        logical graph where vertices store aggregated information about connected edges

      • reduceOnNeighbors

        LogicalGraph reduceOnNeighbors(VertexAggregateFunction function,
                               Neighborhood.EdgeDirection edgeDirection)
        Sets the aggregation result of the given function as property for each vertex. All vertices of relevant edges get joined first and then grouped by the vertex. The relevant edges are specified using the direction which may direct to the vertex, or from the vertex or both.
        Parameters:
        function - aggregate function
        edgeDirection - incoming, outgoing edges or both
        Returns:
        logical graph where vertices store aggregated information about connected vertices

      • equalsByElementIds

        org.apache.flink.api.java.DataSet<Boolean> equalsByElementIds(LogicalGraph other)
        Checks, if another logical graph contains exactly the same vertices and edges (by id) as this graph.
        Parameters:
        other - other graph
        Returns:
        1-element dataset containing true, if equal by element ids

      • equalsByElementData

        org.apache.flink.api.java.DataSet<Boolean> equalsByElementData(LogicalGraph other)
        Checks, if another logical graph contains vertices and edges with the same attached data (i.e. label and properties) as this graph.
        Parameters:
        other - other graph
        Returns:
        1-element dataset containing true, iff equal by element data

      • equalsByData

        org.apache.flink.api.java.DataSet<Boolean> equalsByData(LogicalGraph other)
        Checks, if another logical graph has the same attached data and contains vertices and edges with the same attached data as this graph.
        Parameters:
        other - other graph
        Returns:
        1-element dataset containing true, iff equal by element data

      • groupVerticesByRollUp

        GraphCollection groupVerticesByRollUp(List<String> vertexGroupingKeys,
                                      List<AggregateFunction> vertexAggregateFunctions,
                                      List<String> edgeGroupingKeys,
                                      List<AggregateFunction> edgeAggregateFunctions)
        Generates all combinations of the supplied vertex grouping keys according to the definition of the rollUp operation in SQL and uses them together with all edge grouping keys for separate grouping operations. For example, specifying the vertex grouping keys A, B and C leads to three differently grouped graphs {A,B,C},{A,B},{A} within the resulting graph collection.
        Parameters:
        vertexGroupingKeys - grouping keys to group vertices
        vertexAggregateFunctions - aggregate functions to apply on super vertices
        edgeGroupingKeys - grouping keys to group edges
        edgeAggregateFunctions - aggregate functions to apply on super edges
        Returns:
        graph collection containing all resulting graphs

      • groupEdgesByRollUp

        GraphCollection groupEdgesByRollUp(List<String> vertexGroupingKeys,
                                   List<AggregateFunction> vertexAggregateFunctions,
                                   List<String> edgeGroupingKeys,
                                   List<AggregateFunction> edgeAggregateFunctions)
        Generates all combinations of the supplied edge grouping keys according to the definition of the rollUp operation in SQL and uses them together with all vertex grouping keys for separate grouping operations. For example, specifying the edge grouping keys A, B and C leads to three differently grouped graphs {A,B,C},{A,B},{A} within the resulting graph collection.
        Parameters:
        vertexGroupingKeys - grouping keys to group vertices
        vertexAggregateFunctions - aggregate functions to apply on super vertices
        edgeGroupingKeys - grouping keys to group edges
        edgeAggregateFunctions - aggregate functions to apply on super edges
        Returns:
        graph collection containing all resulting graphs

      • verify

        LogicalGraph verify()
        Verifies this graph, removing dangling edges, i.e. edges pointing to or from a vertex not contained in this graph.
        This operator can be applied after an operator that has not checked the graphs validity. The graph head of this logical graph remains unchanged.
        Returns:
        this graph with all dangling edges removed.

      • combine

        LogicalGraph combine(LogicalGraph otherGraph)
        Creates a new logical graph by combining the vertex and edge sets of this graph and the given graph. Vertex and edge equality is based on their identifiers.
        Parameters:
        otherGraph - logical graph to combine this graph with
        Returns:
        logical graph containing all vertices and edges of the input graphs

      • overlap

        LogicalGraph overlap(LogicalGraph otherGraph)
        Creates a new logical graph containing the overlapping vertex and edge sets of this graph and the given graph. Vertex and edge equality is based on their identifiers.
        Parameters:
        otherGraph - logical graph to compute overlap with
        Returns:
        logical graph that contains all vertices and edges that exist in both input graphs

      • exclude

        LogicalGraph exclude(LogicalGraph otherGraph)
        Creates a new logical graph containing only vertices and edges that exist in that graph but not in the other graph. Vertex and edge equality is based on their identifiers.
        Parameters:
        otherGraph - logical graph to exclude from that graph
        Returns:
        logical that contains only vertices and edges that are not in the other graph

      • splitBy

        GraphCollection splitBy(String propertyKey)
        Splits the graph into multiple logical graphs using the property value which is assigned to the given property key. Vertices and edges that do not have this property will be removed from the resulting collection.
        Parameters:
        propertyKey - split property key
        Returns:
        graph collection

      • callForGraph

        LogicalGraph callForGraph(UnaryBaseGraphToBaseGraphOperator<LogicalGraph> operator)
        Creates a logical graph using the given unary graph operator.
        Parameters:
        operator - unary graph to graph operator
        Returns:
        result of given operator

      • callForGraph

        LogicalGraph callForGraph(BinaryGraphToGraphOperator operator,
                          LogicalGraph otherGraph)
        Creates a logical graph from that graph and the input graph using the given binary operator.
        Parameters:
        operator - binary graph to graph operator
        otherGraph - other graph
        Returns:
        result of given operator

                          LogicalGraph... otherGraphs)

        otherGraphs - other graphs
